On 21/01/2011 22:09, Ken wrote:
> Rob, can you clarify what you mean when you say that keeping the
> complete generation history seems to be the root of the problem? Are you
> saying that something in the system that keeps a history is causing the
> memory to build up?

Yes :-)

It would appear so, but then I'm not too familiar with the inner working 
of NEAT, just the generalisations.

In NEAT_GeneticPopulation.h, the class GeneticPopulation has a stack 
defined as:

vector<shared_ptr<GeneticGeneration> > generations;

and in the function:
void GeneticPopulation::produceNextGeneration()
at the end is:

     generations.push_back(newGeneration);
     onGeneration++;
}

A trace through the code, with the debugger, shows that the generations 
stack grows progressively. I haven't found anything that trims it down. 
In any event, trimming would seem to be problematic, as it is accessed 
using the generation number as an index.

I'm quite happy to be told that I'm talking a load of rubbish, but a 
pointer or two would be appreciated.

-- 
Rob Marsden
Gistix (Northern) Limited
